unnormalised: ## Finding My Shanti: A Journey Through Yoga Practices
normalised: ## Finding My Shanti: A Journey Through Yoga Practices

unnormalised: Namaste friends! For years, I’d seen yoga studios popping up like mushrooms after the monsoon – "Yoga Shala," "Prana Flow," "Ashtanga Haven" - you name it, Delhi had it. But honestly, I was intimidated. All those pretzel poses and Sanskrit chants seemed… inaccessible. I pictured myself, clumsy and inflexible, disrupting a room full of serene yogis.
normalised: Namaste friends! For years, I’d seen yoga studios popping up like mushrooms after the monsoon – "Yoga Shala," "Prana Flow," "Ashtanga Haven" - you name it, Delhi had it. But honestly, I was intimidated. All those pretzel poses and Sanskrit chants seemed… inaccessible. I pictured myself, clumsy and inflexible, disrupting a room full of serene yogis.

unnormalised: Then, Dr. Sharma, my family physician (and a surprisingly limber fellow!), suggested yoga for my chronic back pain. He recommended starting slow, perhaps with a gentle Hatha class at the local community center in Hauz Khas. He even cited a study from AIIMS indicating yoga could reduce back pain by up to 60%!

unnormalised: Armed with this information and a borrowed yoga mat (a rather garish pink one, mind you), I took the plunge. My first class was… humbling. I definitely wobbled during tree pose (Vrksasana) and struggled to touch my toes in Uttanasana. But the instructor, Priya, was incredibly supportive. She emphasized listening to my body and modifying poses as needed.

unnormalised: Over time, I've explored different yoga practices. I discovered I quite enjoy Vinyasa flow, the dynamic movements syncing with my breath. It’s a great way to start the day, clearing the cobwebs and energizing me for whatever Delhi throws my way. Restorative yoga, with its emphasis on supported poses and deep relaxation, has been a lifesaver for managing stress, especially during peak wedding season (it feels like everyone I know is getting married!).

unnormalised: I even ventured into a Bikram yoga class once, held in a room heated to a sweltering 105 degrees! Let’s just say that was a one-time experience. I prefer my yoga a little less… sauna-like.
normalised: I even ventured into a Bikram yoga class once, held in a room heated to a sweltering one hundred and five degrees! Let’s just say that was a one-time experience. I prefer my yoga a little less… sauna-like.

unnormalised: Now, several months in, I’m not a yoga master by any means. I can still barely touch my toes! But I'm feeling stronger, more flexible, and definitely less stressed. My back pain has significantly reduced, allowing me to enjoy long walks in Lodhi Garden again. I even managed to meditate for 10 minutes straight this morning (a personal record!).

unnormalised: Yoga isn't about achieving some perfect pose or fitting into a certain mold. It's about connecting with your body, finding your breath, and cultivating a sense of inner peace. It doesn’t require a fancy studio (though a 500 sq ft room would be nice!), expensive leggings, or the ability to contort yourself into unimaginable positions. Just a willingness to try and a bit of patience. And maybe a less garish yoga mat than mine. Rs. 1000 well spent for that upgrade! I'm still learning, still exploring, and still finding my shanti, one asana at a time.
